thread.title: Treasury yields record largest 2-week decline in 4 months
thread.title_full: Treasury yields record largest 2-week decline in 4 months - MarketWatch

author: By     Ellie Ismailidou
title: Treasury yields record largest 2-week decline in 4 months
text:
Weighed down by a global-commodity slump and wobbly stocks, Treasury yields finished lower for a second week on Friday, recording the largest two-week decline since March 27.
Treasury yields, which move inversely to prices, have been falling throughout the week and their descent persisted on Friday as investors continued to buy assets perceived to be safe like Treasurys.
A dearth of significant market-moving data resulted in thinner trading volumes, as stocks slumped and economic data, including June’s new home sales declined and the purchasing-managers index , pointed to slowing growth.
Weak economic data out of China, where the flash purchasing-managers index fell to its lowest level since March 2014 , along with gold’s slide , also put further downward pressure on yields.
The yield on the 10-year Treasury TMUBMUSD10Y, -0.23% fell 0.7 basis point to 2.271% on Friday and shaved off 7.7 basis points over the week, according to Tradeweb. The yield on the two-year TMUBMUSD02Y, -1.72% note fell 1.6 basis point to 0.682% on Friday but rose 1.3 basis point over the week. The yield on the 30-year bond TMUBMUSD30Y, -0.22% declined two basis points to 2.959% on Friday and 12.1 basis points over the week.
A flattening yield curve has been another theme throughout the week, with long maturities leading the move, as 30-year yields crossed below 2.960%—the lowest point since early June.
When the yield curve flattens, it means that the spread, or yield differential, between long-term and short-term Treasury bonds is decreasing.
The falling long-term yields are mainly due to the disinflationary effect of the commodity slump, because long-term yields are most sensitive to inflation whereas short-term yields are more sensitive to Fed rate-hike expectations, said Ilya Feygin, managing director at WallachBeth Capital.
Read: How the commodity crisis has divided bond investors
Lower commodities also affect the dollar, which the Federal Reserve has stated is one of its main concerns ahead of the first interest-rate increase in nearly a decade.
“Lower commodities strengthen the dollar and a stronger dollar keeps the Fed away,” Feygin said.
In Europe, government bonds were also rallying Friday, after investors received slightly weaker-than-expected readings in eurozone manufacturing and services data. Market watchers were also following the Greek debt situation, where the debt-burdened country and its creditors were set to open talks Friday to complete a bailout deal.
While stock markets in Europe rose slightly , yields were 3.5 to 8.5 basis points lower across the eurozone. The yield on the benchmark German 10-year bund TMBMKDE-10Y, -7.43% fell 5.7 basis points to 0.650%.
